Suit hits Pentagon over 2011 data breach

A class-action lawsuit is seeking unspecified damages for one of the largest-ever breaches of medical data that plaintiffs blame on a Pentagon contractor. (Boston Globe)

Price honors slain friend with youth program

Ex-basketball star Kendric Price teaches the Xs and Os of Capitalism 101 to boys whose innocent eyes remind him of his slain friend.

Before the Celtics make a run at the conference finals, they must beat these Atlanta Hawks. And that’s proving to be a little harder than it should be.

Social media blitz lands Dave a job

Dave Cutler’s frenzy of social media self-promotion paid off in April when he landed a job as a social media specialist.

Seaport District to get new tower

The developer of the massive Channel Center complex is proposing construction of an 11-story office building, public parks, and a parking garage.
Opinion | Dante Ramos

Are you ‘diverse’?

For mixed-race Americans who mean neither to exploit their ancestry nor minimize it, brushing aside the issue is harder than it seems.

Alzheimer’s program has special meaning for Harvard student

Every Sunday, Harvard pre-med student Ryan Christ goes to a Roslindale nursing home to visit the woman he calls his mentor, an 85-year-old physician named Sofia Itkis.
Opinion | Lawrence Harmon

Boston’s deadliest hour

Extending club licenses to 3 or 4 a.m. would give police a better opportunity to arrest troublemakers.

Hundreds march as Japan
goes without nuclear power

"No nukes" banners waved to celebrate the last of Japan's 50 nuclear reactors switching off. After last year's quake and tsunami, no reactor stopped for checkups has gone back up.

He will need independents in November, but Mitt Romney isn't abandoning his "severely conservative" record. Instead, he has launched an aggressive campaign that straddles two sometimes-conflicting political ideologies.
